A. Constraintsto PrivateSector DevelopmentinAfghanistan'
1. Electric Power. As in many developing countries, inadequate and unreliable power supply i s a major constraint on private sector activity, particularly in the industrial sector. According to the Afghanistan Investment Climate Assessment (ICA) carried out in 2005, inadequate power supply i s the most important constraint faced by Afghan investors. 64 percent o f surveyed firms cited this as a major or severe constraint; for one city, Le., Jalalabad, this figure i s 90 percent. Due to a combination o f the direct effects o f war, a lack o f maintenance, and the theft o f spare parts and equipment - the power supply i s erratic and unreliable. In addition to generation problems, Afghanistan has no national grid and suffers from severe transmission and distribution limitations. Lack o f adequate power supply increases costs for private firms who are forced to make alternative arrangements.
2. Land. Unclear ownership o f land i s a major constraint to investment inAfghanistan. According to the I C A survey, this is the second most important constraint faced by Afghan investors with 60 percent o f the surveyed firms identifying this as a major or severe constraint. Land titling in Afghanistan i s difficult and multiple ownership documents exist for the same piece o f land. The return o f refugees i s compounding the problem, with disputes being common. The scope for resolving disputes through the court system i s limited given inadequate court capacity, small number o f judges with necessary legal expertise and insufficient guidance provided by law. Property rights are thus unclear and insecure. Land cannot be collateralized easily and hence cannot be used to generate financial resources or set up small businesses.
3. Access tofinance. Banking services in Afghanistan remain severely limited. The passage o f the Central Banking Law and the Commercial Banking Law in September 2003, and the entry o f several commercial banks mark significant progress. But there i s much to be done before financial services are restored to a level required for meaningful trade and investment activities. The state financial institutions, which have the largest national infrastructure, are largely non-functional although Government i s contemplating measures to revive the good assets in two public sector banks and channel them in ways that improve access to finance. Some o f the new private banks are lending to industrybut on a very small scale. Local enterprises suffer from a shortage o f capital, and trading activity and industrial development have been adversely affected. Access to finance was listed as the fourth most important constraint by firms surveyed for the Afghanistan Investment Climate Assessment (2005); it was cited by 51 percent o f the firms as a major or severe constraint.
4. Labor. Because o f the low literacy levels and lack o f other formal training facilities, qualified management level staff i s scarcely available and most labor training takes place on the job. This problem i s exacerbated by barriers against women being employed in certain jobs, as well as a dysfunctional education system in terms o f preparing students to exploit future labor market opportunities. Because such formal employment opportunities are very few, hrther skill enhancement, including that for women, i s not forthcoming. The weak legal framework within the country implies an unclear definition o f labor rights. As a result, it i s difficult to develop and enforce contracts.

1  5. Security. Security remains a major problem for private enterprises in Afghanistan although the severity may differ between locations. Poor security increases the risks o f investment, and thereby deters investors, particularly foreign investors, who have other places to invest. Poor security also raises the costs for existing businesses, e.g., through the need to hire security guards. It also raises transport costs in general by imposing limitations on operating hours, restricting the flexibility of truck operations, and sometimes requiring the use of convoy systems. According to the 2005 ICA, firms spend, on average, 15 percent o f their revenues in addressing security needs. This i s at least five times higher than the security costs incurredby firms inother countries inthe region.
6. Risk mitigation. Insecurity as well as other factors such as the country's fragile economic situation, coupled with weak legal and regulatory frameworks for the private sector, and a hugely undevelopedjudicial system increases the perceived political risk of doing business inAfghanistan. While there i s real and substantial interest from foreign private investors inAfghanistan, and strong government encouragement o f FDI, the political risks will act as a major impediment to FDI flows to the country. Domestically, also, Afghanistan i s acutely under insured. The Afghan National Insurance Company (ANIC), the sole insurance company operating in the country, enjoys a monopoly on all insurance functions, suffers fiom a lack o f trained staff and has a poor track record in paying out on legitimate claims. Lack o f insurance has a serious effect on private sector activity. For example, most international shipping lines do not allow their containers into the country. Within Afghanistan, cargo moves under either owners' risk or carriers' liability (at much higher freight rates), both o f which discourage trade. Without guarantees against political risks, many investors will be unwilling to do business in Afghanistan.2
7. Transport and trade logistics. Transit related trade costs are high in Afghanistan due to inefficiencies in the present transit system including: a) non-existent, or poor state, o f trade and transit infrastructure, b) very poor condition o f the road network; c) the short internal hauls on many o f the transit routes; d) insecurity; and, e) the numerous checkpoints along the routes. With limited exception o f some direct road transport from Karachi to Kabul, all o f Afghanistan's foreign trade i s transshipped, which raises costs directly (e.g., handling charges) and indirectly (loss and damage). International shipping lines do not allow their containers into the country. Most o f the cargo, subjected to multiple handling, i s thus break bulk cargo, and most vulnerable to handling loss and damage. Coordination between transporters in Afghanistan and transit countries, and between shippers and customs officials, i s poor because o f the lack o f professional transit agents and poor communications. A local freight- forwarding industry existed and was very active prior to 1975, but i s non-existent today. There are no norms o f accreditation for fieight-forwarders. Some international freight-forwarders are currently operating inAfghanistan.
8. Regulatory burden. Although there have been improvements in the regulatory regime, such as streamlining o f the business registration, customs procedures and trade licensing systems, there are still numerous examples o f excessive regulatory burdens. For example, the transaction costs o f transporting goods within Afghanistan are raised directly by multiple fees and taxes, and indirectly by the delays and uncertainties that the multiple checkpoints along the routes i m p ~ s eProvincial agencies interfere with . ~ operations by often imposing informal procedural requirements. While business registration and overall trade licensing have been streamlined, obtaining specific licenses, e.g., for operating in certain sector such as pharmaceuticals, may still take considerable time. Onerous regulatory procedures are often associated with corruption. The 2005 ICA identifies corruption as the thirdmost important constraint faced by investors with 53% o f the surveyed firms citing this as a major or severe constraint.
9. Legal framework for private sector development. Private sector development requires a conducive legal framework and a fair and effective judicial system. Disputes need to be settled and contracts enforced. Propertyrights and investment need to be adequately protected. Businesses needto be able to start up easily, to function efficiently while they are inoperation, and to exit the market in a timely and efficient manner. Afghanistan has inheritedmany laws, regulations and procedures that tend to inhibit trade and investment instead o f encouraging it. An active program o f legal reforms i s currently underway in Afghanistan with considerable donor support although the proposed investment law has faced considerable delays in gaining approval. Adaptation o f foreign laws to the Afghan context and translations o f English drafts are important challenges to legislative reform in Afghanistan. Also important i s the need to enhance the enforcement o f legal decisions; unless such enforcement can be ensured, the legalreforms underway will not have the desired impact.
10. Quality and standards. Afghanistan has no metrology, standards, testing and quality (MSTQ) infrastructure; as a result the country i s often a dumping ground for sub-standard goods. Export development i s inhibited given the high quality standards now demanded by international markets, especially for ago-based products. Without a proper MSTQ system, enterprises are unable to access information related to standards, calibration and product testing facilities. Existing limited arrangements for quality control are generally ineffective. The Government i s now taking modest steps towards setting up a quality system with a National Standards, Metrology and Quality Board having been established recently.
11. Assets locked up in non-functional state-owned enterprises. Afghanistan has about 65 state owned enterprises many o f which are defunct and none o f them are operating at full capacity. There are another 13 state-owned commercial entities that are registered under the Corporations and not called SOEs but could be considered as SOEs for all practical purposes. In addition, several line ministries have a wide activities of commercial activities, including real estate, that are organized as budgetary units. Most SOEs lack resources to carry out major restructuring. Moreover, many are overstaffed and lack management capability to increase capacity utilization. Many SOEs have considerable amount o f surplus land attached to them that i s not required to operate the enterprises.
12. Private sector capacity constraints. The private sector suffers from serious capacity constraints. One manifestation o f i s in the construction industry,where participation o f Afghan companies has been constrained by limited experience, insufficient equipment and unfamiliarity with competitive tendering procedures. In general, the private sector needs assistance in accessing market information, business development services, technology and managerial know-how. There i s need for a critical mass o f private sector service providers in these areas. Since many o f these services may not amenable to full-cost recovery at least not initially, public-private partnerships will be required.
13. Institutional framework for private sector development policy. Several ministries and agencies have responsibilities related to private sector development. Coordination among these bodies is critical. The High Commission for Investment provides a forum for such coordination but procedures and practices must be in place to encourage coordination without necessarily having to go through the High Commission. The Government has established AISA with a mandate to promote foreign investment and facilitate business. Established inAugust 2003, AISA i s faced with the challenge o f attracting investment ina tough global marketplace that has little positive information about the country. It has made a good  beginning with regard to facilitating investors but i s still in the early stages o f developing its corporate identity, strategy, andbusiness plan. At the request of the Government, the World Bank Group conducted an assessment o f AISA in order to identify areas o f comparative strength and constraint. This assessment was followed by a three-year business plan, developed by MIGA with an aim to identify actions that will help AISA to become a world-class investment promotion intermediary. Recently, AISA has developed an organizational restructuringplan, drawing partly upon the business plan.
14. An important aspect o fthe institutional framework for PSD is the role o fprivate sector collective bodies and their interaction with the government. The Afghan Chamber o f Commerce, which has existed for many years, i s essentially a government agency with a number o f regulatory functions. The future o f this institutionis under discussion - it appears that the government intends to streamline its functions and convert it to a truly private sector chamber. Meanwhile, a number o f independent private sector collective bodies have emerged and are active. These include the Afghanistan International Chamber o f Commerce (AICC), the Afghan-American Chamber o f Commerce (AACC) and several sectoral associations. The Government has recently appointed a commission to develop a vision for the development o f chambers o f commerce in the country, including deciding the future o f the quasi-government Afghan Chamber o f Commerce.
15. Export promotion. Greater export orientation i s an important aspect o f the Government's private sector development vision. This will require a successful export promotion effort involving collaboration between the public and private sectors. The Export Promotion Department in the M o C has an explicit mandate to promote and facilitate exports. However, it suffers from weak capacity, including lack o f many basic shlls, and has lost contacts in developed countries after the shift in trade flows away from these countries since the mid-1970s. The Government i s seriously considering revamping its export promotion efforts.
B. GovernmentResponses
16. Macro-economic stability and fiscal reforms. The GOA has been remarkably successful in establishing a stable macro-economic environment. Currency reform was completed in early 2003 and since then inflation has been around 10 per cent and the currency stable. The government has shown strong fiscal discipline and has implemented a no overdraft policy where they refrain from printing money to finance a deficit. The government has also followed a prudent debt policy and has sought most o f its external assistance in grants or highly concessional credits. The tax code was restructured in 2004 to expand and simplify the code. The gross profit tax rate is now 21.4 percent, compared with 35 percent for the region and 46 percent inthe Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).
17. External trade. The government has taken a number o f steps to foster trade and reestablish relationships with trading partners. Customs tariffs have been rationalized, existing trade agreements have been renewed and new agreements entered. The government has promised to build a trade regime that will allow Afghanistan to enter the World Trade Organization within the next few years. Trade has increased dramatically with the value o f annual exports and imports growing at double digit levels. However, most o f the exports are re-exports to Pakistan suggesting that the increase in trade does not reflect an increase inAfghanistan's international competitiveness.
18. Financial sector reforms. There has been significant progress indeveloping the financial sector. The D a Afghanistan Bank (DAB) and Banking Laws have been gazetted (i.e., formally enacted) and a number o f commercial banks licensed. DAB has divested its headquarters-based commercial banking activities and divestment will be extended to branches in provinces where commercial banks are active. Three state-owned banks (Mille, Pashtany, and Export Promotion) have been relicensed, with corrective
4  action provisions to improve performance. Progress has also been made in developing the microfinance sector.
19. Emphasis on private sector development. The government has clearly recognized that Afghanistan's success will depend upon its ability to quickly develop a strong and vibrant private sector. Private sector development i s one o f the priority areas for the Afghanistan National Development Strategy (ANDs), which is the GOA's overarching strategy for promoting growth, generatingwealth and reducing poverty and vulnerability. The World Bank's Interim Support Strategy strongly supports GOA's strategy. However, to meet this strategy and implement private sector dominance inthe economy, there i s need for stronger GOA commitment to address private sector constrains pertaining to economic and physical infrastructure, regulatoryregime and corruption.
20. Institutions for private sector development. The Government established the Afghanistan Investment Support Agency (AISA) in 2003 as an independent institution with its own organizational structure. AISA's core function i s domestic and foreign investment promotion. This comprises registrationo f business to provide a legal identity, facilitation for obtaining other approvals required to set up or operate a business and investment promotional work within and outside the country, e.g., organization o f business workshop and trade fare or road show, etc. The other function that AISA performs i s to facilitate construction o f industrial parks to alleviate land problems o f the investors. This function i s undertaken by the Industrial Parks Department, created within AISA. AISA has had a good track so far in facilitating business entry. It has helped register about 3500 firms since its establishment in August 2003. It is planning to open regional offices and is preparing papers on sectoral opportunities. With United Nations Development Program (UNDP) assistance, AISA has also completed work on a database o f 6000 companies which were registered prior to the establishment o f AISA. The runningcosts o f AHA are partly funded by GTZ on a decreasing scale. This i s for 4 years and will end in 2007. However, AISA earns substantial income from licenses which i s adequate to meet its current operational costs. Going forward, one o f the main challenges for AISA i s long-term institutional development, especially inthe area o f investment support and policy advocacy.
21. The PRR Stage 1 application for the Ministry o f Commerce (MoCI) was approved in August 2005 followed by approval o f the PRR Stage 2 application in June 2006. The restructuring in the Ministry has led to the creation of a number of directorates. In addition to the functional directorates dealing with human resources, finance, administration, and research and planning, there are four thematic directorates dealing with: a) International Trade, b) Transit and Trade Facilitation, c) Private Sector Development, and d) State-owned Enterprises. The Ministry has come up with a capacity building program with the objective o f developing the policy formulation, implementation and evaluation skills and knowledge appropriate to each level o f personnel.
22. Infrastructure and utilities. A power sector master plan outlining an investment program to help rebuild the power infrastructure has been adopted. Implementation o f the investment program has started and has focused on rehabilitation o f damaged generation capacity for Kabul and Kandahar, construction o f transmission lines from existing hydro plants to Kabul, and the Northern Transmission System, which will allow import o f lowcost power from Uzbekistan to Kabul (expected completion by end o f 2008). In addition, there is investment inrehabilitation and expansion o fthe distribution systems inKabul and other cities. There i s also a proposal for a combined cycle generation turbine plant at Shebergan that could add lOOMW to 150MW o f generation capacity and is a good opportunity for an international management contract. There are three private mobile operators (one o f these was recently licensed). Competition between the privately owned mobile networks has resulted in prices consistent with international noms. The publicly owned, fixed-line telecom provider, Afghan Tel has been corporatized. Rehabilitating the roadnetwork has been a top priority for the government, which has developed a large investment program for major highways, including rehabilitation o f the existing network, completion o f the network, and, over
5  time; construction o f new roads. Despite some delays there have been noticeable improvements in some areas with some improvements intravel times already beginning to materialize. Inaddition to work on the main highways, there have been efforts to repair and improve smaller roads, primarily through public works employment programs, most notably the National Emergency Employment Program. Nonetheless, there i s still a long way to go inrehabilitating the highway system and completing its segments including the remaining "ring" connection in Northwest Afghanistan. In addition, the government has revived Ariana, the public sector airline and licensed a number o f private airlines.

Arrangements for resultsmonitoring
The Industrial Parks Department and the recently created Policy and Research Department in the Afghanistan Investment Support Agency will have overall responsibility for implementing the results monitoring system as well as specific responsibility for monitoring the results o f the industrial park and AISA-capacity building components o f the project. In addition, the Private Sector Development Department in the M o C I will implement the results monitoring system for the capacity buildingprogram in the Ministry.The project will also support the development and implementation of a broader results monitoring system for PSD issues and results monitoring for the project components will be part of this process. The specific arrangements for the specific components are discussed below and summarized in the Table.
i) Industrial park component. The industrial parks component will support the construction o f one industrial park as well as the development o f policy, regulatory and institutional capacity for an overall industrial park development program. The results monitoring framework will cover both aspects. For the industrial park to be supported by the project, each tenant will be required to submit data on a prescribed format to the Industrial Parks Department in AISA. While AISA may require more frequent reporting for i t s own purposes, the project will require quarterly reporting on production, employment, sales and exports, and annual reporting on investments. The Industrial Park Department will collate the data and provide them to IDA within a month after receiving them from the enterprises. The Department will also provide quarterly progress reports to IDA during the construction phase o f the park. These progress reports will include information on the progress with park construction, allocation o f plots, and construction o f factory buildings by tenants and commissioning o f plants. This monitoring exercise is separate from the monitoring o f environmental practices and work place conditions, which will be part o f the environmental and social management plan (discussed inAnnex 10).
Progress with regardto the policy, regulatory and institutional framework for industrialpark development will be monitored by examining the drafting and enactment o frelevant policies, laws andregulations.
ii;, AISA institutional development and capacity building. The results monitoring framework for this component will have two .parts. This will be similar to the assessment carried out in late 2004 which will serve as a benchmark. The second dimension o f the results framework will assess the efficacy o f AISA's investment facilitation function. The recently created Policy and Research Department inAISA will oversee the collection o f data for this. Itwill collaborate with the private sector chambers inthe collection and interpretationo fthe data.

Component1: Developmentof industrialparks(US$24.00m.)
The GOA has identified industrial park development as an important plank o f its private sector development strategy. It plans to develop industrial parks in various parts o f Afghanistan in an effort to engender regional balance in industrial growth. It also proposes to involve the private sector in the development and operation o f the estates.
The emphasis on industrial park development i s a response to the difficulties investors face in acquiring land with a clear title for setting up production facilities. Industrial parks are also viewed as an effective means o f focusing the provision o f infrastructural and utility services, currently in short supply in Afghanistan. The parks will provide physical infrastructure that guarantees a high degree o f self sufficiency in terms o f essential utilities such as water and power supply, collection ad treatment o f liquid as well as solid wastes. Given the difficult socio-economic and post conflict conditions in Afghanistan and the nation's tremendous capital needs for reconstruction investments, the Government i s anxious to ensure the economical utilization o f scarce funds. Finally, industrial parks will provide a secure environment to carry out production activities. The concentration o f a critical mass o f industrial enterprises in a park will also facilitate the provision o f business development services to the firms as well as generate opportunities for firm-to-firm learning and knowledge diffusion.
The institutional mandate for industrial park development i s in the process o f being clarified. Historically, the Ministry o f Light Industry was in charge o f the industrial park development program. With the creation o f a combined Commerce and IndustryMinistry,this mandate has now passed to the new ministry. The Ministry, however, has very limited capacity to run an effective industrial parks program. A new department has been created within AISA and given responsibility for developing specific industrial parks, such as the three parks currently under development in Bagrami (near Kabul), Mazar-e-Sharif and Kandahar, and the two parks to be supported by this project. AISA expects the entire responsibility for industrial park development to be vested in them. However, a decision on this has not yet been taken.
The Government recognizes the importance o f an adequate policy, regulatory and institutional framework for industrial park development, including private participation in the development and management o f the parks. A. Country Context
The Bank has gained substantial experience and understanding o f the procurement environment in Afghanistan through its involvement in the interim procurement arrangements put in place through EPAP as well as with the institutions with current responsibility for those and the subsequent arrangements, namely ARDS. As part o f the broader review of Afghanistan's Public Finance Management (PFM) system, the Bank carried out an assessment o f the procurement environment in the country based on the baseline and performance indicators developed by a group o f institutions led by the World Bank and OECD/DAC.
The first key issue identified through the procurement assessment was the need for ownership and a champion in the Government for reform, deepening o f capacity, ensuring integrity in the operation o f procurement systems, and promoting sound procurement among ministries.
A new Procurement Law has beenadopted inNovember 2005 whichradically transforms the legal and regulatory framework. While it provides a very modem legal system for procurement, it may be difficult to implement inthe current context. The Procurement Policy Unit (PPU) has now been established under the MOF to ensure implementationthrough the creation o f secondary legislation, standardbidding documents, provision o f advice and creation o f the necessary information systems for advertising and data collection. It further relies on the development o f an independent complaints review mechanismto ensure enforcement. These institutional arrangements are yet to be inplace.
In the absence of adequate capacity to manage procurement activities effectively, some interim arrangements have been put inplace to improve the procurement management o f the country. A central procurement facilitation service has been established under A R D S which i s supervised by the Ministry o f Economy. The Bank and the Government has agreed on a program for country wide procurement reform and capacity building, leading to the transition from centralized to decentralized procurement services. The Bank funded Public Administration Capacity Buildingproject (PACBP) i s the primary instrument for implementing the program to strengthen capacity o f the line ministries to manage public procurement in an effective, transparent and accountable manner. However, the implementation o f the procurement capacity building strategy has not made any significant progress yet due to lack o f coordination and delays in decision making within the Government. The envisaged radical changes to the procurement management environment expected from the new Law also require the urgent implementation o f a comprehensive human resources and capacity development program. The implementation o f the procurement reform component o f the PACBP should be considered with due priority to ensure that fiduciary standards are further enhanced and that capacity i s developed in the Government to maintain these standards.

Scarcity o f data and the high level o f uncertainty in Afghanistan make it difficult to cany out a rigorous financial and economy analysis o f the project. The problem i s compounded by two additional factors. Firstly,given the current low incidence of industrial activity inAfghanistan, the emergence o f about 200 small and medium scale enterprises, clustered in two important locations, i s likely to have a wide range o f spill over effects. While industrial activity anywhere has a spill over impact, the impact i s usually substantial where the initial base i s small. Such spill over effects are difficult to measure, especially in a country with little track record and paucity o f data. Thus, while this analysis tries to take into spill-over effects, the results will most likely grossly underestimate the true returns from the investment. The second source o f an underestimate i s the difficulties o f assessing returns from capacity buildingactivities, which account for an important part o f the project. Because o f such difficulties, the capacity buildingcomponent o f the project has not been included in the quantitative analysis that follows. Again, in a country where the initial base (of capacity) i s low, capacity building efforts, especially in important agencies, strategic agencies, i s likely to have a significant spill over impact going beyond the agencies themselves. These caveats needto be kept inmindwhile assessing the results o fthe financial and economic analysis. The analysis focuses on the Hissar-e-Shahi industrial park to be supported by the project and covers a time period o f 20 years. The costs include the cost o fbuildingand operating the park. The benefits stream relate to the most important stakeholders o f the project and include the following:

The proposed Hissar-e-Shahi Industrial Park will cover an area o f 106 hectares and will be located about 25 km from Jalalabad City on the northern side o f the main highway to Torkham.' The proposed industrial park will comprise o f the following industries: a) light engineering; b) food processing; c) leather garments; and d) carpet washing and finishing. The specific industries that private investors will establish within the broad categories o f light engineering and food processing i s not known at this stage. The proposed Kamari Industrial Park will be located in Bagrami District, about 10 km east o f Kabul on the Kabul - Jalalabad road just beyond the existing Bagrami Industrial Park. Moreover, the analysis o f canal water indicates that while it can be used for firefighting and other purposes it i s not fit for drinking. The option o f usingthe other source, i.e. ground water, was investigated. Duringreconnaissance survey o f the project area it was observed that shallow tube wells exist within the project site and its adjoining areas and ground water i s available at a depth o f about 40m to 50m. Samples o f existing water samples were collected from the site and tested against the WHO drinking water quality parameters. The results were found satisfactory. Hence, at Hissar-e-Shahi, water will be supplied from shallow tube wells within the project site and its adjoining areas where ground water i s available at a depth o f about 40m to 50m.. The dominant family size group inthe project area has between 3 and 4 family members and, inthe study area, between 5 and 6 members. The female population i s about 49 per cent. Illiteracy rates are high, about 80% and most working members o f the households work as laborers or servants. 95% o f the households in the project area use water from community tube wells on payment and only 5 % carry water from Nangarhar Canal. In the study area, 50% households obtain their water from the community tube wells and 50% from Nangarhar Canal. N o household in either the project or study area has access to electricity. N o proper sanitatioddrainage facilities are available and waste water i s disposed o f in the open spaces just outside the houses. Telephone, Post Office, Metalled road facilities are not available in the Project and Study Area. However, these facilities are available in Jalalabad city. There i s only one school inthe Study Area located inthe Kabul Camp; it i s usedbothby girls and boys. The buildingo f the school i s in poor condition. There are only two dispensaries in the Study Area and only two private clinics.
Prejudice against female education i s strong and most o f the respondents. Female respondents in the area informed that there was no lady doctor, trained lady health visitors or maternity homes inthe area and are constrained by the Pardah (veil) system from going outside and receiving treatment. They travel outside the village only in a serious condition to get treatment from the hospital in Jalalabad City or to attend weddings o f relatives. Three maternal death cases have been reported during the last one year. The women have no formal role inthe authority structure o f the villages inthe Project and Study Areas.
Settlements around Hessar-e-Shahi Industrial P a r k
Hissar-e-Shahi Camp.The Hissar-e-Shahi camp is partly located inthe Project Area and partly inthe Study Area. The people living in this camp are Pashto speaking Afghan Muhajreen (refugees), originally from Kunar Province (Afghanistan), and residing at this site for the last one and a half year. Their main occupation is labor. The camp i s located at an approximate distance o f a half kilometer (km) from main road is accessible through a dirt track. The camp completely lacks infrastructural facilities. The residents fetch water from an existing tubewell located about 1 km from the site by paying Rs.50 /month to the contractor. The residents are prone to water borne diseases due to lack o f sanitation facilities.
26 families were residing inthe area o f Hissar-e-Shahi camp that lies within the Project Area limits. During the focus group discussion conducted by the environmental and social consultants in the camp area, it was revealed that the people are happy about the proposed project but requires compensation for relocation.
Kabul Camp. The Kabul Camp i s located in the Study Area o f the proposed Park and was constructed in the early nineties. The camp comprises nine blocks and each block has 170 houses with an approximate

There i s only one primary school for both boys and girls near the Kabul Camp. The camp lacks in institutional and civic facilities. Water for domestic use i s self carried from a community tubewell by paying Rs.50 /month to the contractor. The influential people have their own water taps in their houses and pay Rs. 350Imonth water charges to the contractor. The pressing needs o f the Kabul Camp residents, as articulated through a survey, are hospital, high school, transport, electricity and water etc.
Chora Gali. The village Chora Gali i s located on the right bank o f Nangarhar Canal about 25 km from Jalalabad city and 3 km from the main road (Thorkham-Jalalabad). The people living in Chora Gali are Afghan Muhajreen from the following tribes: Mola Khail, Mian Khail and Mulla Khail. Pashto is the only language spoken inthis village. Around 650 houses exist inthe village which has a population o f 5100. As inother cases, the village lacks ineducational, institutional andcivic facilities. A few residents usually shift to Kabul City during the summer season. The residents use Nangarhar Canal as the main source o f water for both domestic as well as drinking purposes. The main diseases afflicting the villagees are Malaria, Typhoid, Diarrhea and Tuberculosis etc. Maliks are the influential people o f this village. Pure drinking water, hospital, school, transport and electricity are the pressing needs o f this village.
Nachaabad. The Nachaabad village i s located northwest o f the proposed industrial park at an approximate distance o f 4.5 km. The Pashto speaking people living in this village are basically from Rodat District and are locals. The village is accessible from the proposed Industrial Park through a dirt track whereas an independent road connects this village to main Torkham-Jalalabad road. The main source o f income i s through agricultural activities. The only and the nearest source o f surface water i s Nangarhar Canal and agricultural activities are dependent on this source. For drinking purposes, mostly community shallow pumps are being utilized. The village altogether lacks inbasic amenities, infrastructure etc. however, the living conditions o f residents of this village are much better in comparison to other villages described above.
The sample survey findings show that the average monthly income i s US$69 in the Project Area and US$121 in the Study Area. Resettlement issues
The land acquisition for the parks will be carried out according to the land acquisition laws o f Afghanistan, Section-40 o f the Constitution o f Afghanistan contains relevant legal provisions for the compulsory acquisition o f land in the public welfare. Land being used for the development o f Hissar-e- Shahi IndustrialPark belongs to the government (Canal Department), therefore no compensation for land i s foreseen.
There are some resettlement issues regarding the Hissar-e-Shahi site. Twenty six families had been residing inthe Project Area o f the Hissar-e-Shahi site. They were living intemporary mudhuts with a tent or plastic cover as ceiling. All o f them are immigrants and had been residing at the site on a temporarily basis (a list o f the affectees i s provided in the Environmental Management Plan document). Almost all the affected persons are relatives o f each other and their huts are located in isolation from nearby settlements.
AISA started consultation with these affectees for the evacuation of site prior to the issue o f the Draft EIA report. Three major meetings between AISA and the affectees were held. The first meeting was held on June 19, 2006 which was also attended by the environmental consultants. As per the demand o f the affectees, a compensation payment o f U S $100 per family plus one tent worth $ 100 for each family was approved by AISA. This i s a fairly generous compensation since the mud walls for one hut can be put together by two unskilled laborers in one day, which would cost in labor terms US$5 given the current wage rate o f US$ 2.5 per day for unskilled workers. The evacuation process was completed on August 18, 2006 as per agreement between AISA and the affectees. The families have been relocated to an adjacent government land. The process i s documented inthe EIA.
There are only three permanent structures in the project area. These are constructed o f burnt brick masonry walls in cement mortar with precast concrete roof. They were constructed for the Administration o f the Kabul Camp but are now abandoned with no doors and windows and the concrete roof largely removed. These are to be demolished but no compensation will be required to be paid to anybody. There i s a possibility that during the project construction, the contractor or the client may rehabilitate the structure for their use and remove them at the end without any cost to the client.
There are four structures wholly on the proposed site; three at the Northern boundary and one at the south-west comer boundary. Details o f these buildingsare provided inthe ESIA. One o f the buildingsi s a de-mining stores building. It i s in a bad condition and needs to be demolished although, after some renovation it could be used as a site office duringthe construction o f the park and eventually demolished. There i s a small room close to the De-mining Stores building which could be used as a store during construction and then demolished. There i s an observation tower and office building, also in poor condition which could be used temporarily during construction and then demolished, All these buildings are inpoor shape and owned by the Government; hence, no compensation i s required.
Two structures are partly within the original site demarcation. These include the boundary wall o f one cemented house and part o f a residential compound. As first household i s unwilling to remove the boundary wall, and the second i s unwilling to relocate, the site demarcation was slightly modified to by- pass these structure. Hence, there are no resettlement issues in Kamari. However, as in Hissar-e-Shahi, there could be opportunities to generate a range o f benefits for the households in the Study Area o f the Kamari Park (see discussion inAttachment 4 under Social Management Plan).
59  The Environmental and Social Manapement Plan
Environmental Management Plans have been prepared for both parks, based on the environmental and preliminary social assessments. These plans lists the mitigation and remedial measures to be implemented during the construction and operation o f the parks to minimize, redress and alleviate the impact o f water and air pollution, noise, chemical & biological pollution from industrial activities, and the impact o f the requisite services network including on land use. Specifically, the EMPs:
outline the mitigation measures requiredto avoid or minimize the negative impacts. develop a monitoring mechanism and identify the monitoring indicators for assessing effectiveness o f the mitigation measures. define the roles and responsibilities o f the implementing agency, AHA, in implementing the EMPs and identify areas where these roles and responsibilities can be shared with other parties involved in the execution and monitoring o fthe Project. define the requirements necessary for documenting compliance with the E M P and communicating it to all concerned regulatory agencies. prescribe the mechanisms for on-going consultation with stakeholders during project implementation.
The EMPs will be part o f contract and tender documents to ensure that the cost o f EMP implementation i s built into the contractor costs. The Contractor will be legally bound for the execution and implementation o f the EMP. AISA with the help o f an independent monitoring company (see below for details on the company) will ensure that coordination with project stakeholders on environmental and social matters as requiredby the EMP i s maintainedthroughout the implementationperiod o f the project.
For each park, the EMP includes a detailed Mitigation Management Matrix that summarizes the mitigation measures for both the construction and operational stages and, for each measure, identifies the agencies that would be responsible for monitoring and management. Athough the responsibilities for executing and monitoring the mitigation measures has been delegated to different organizations, AISA will hold the primary responsibility for ensuring the full implementation o f the EMP. AISA and the contractors will ensure that the mitigation measures mentioned in the Mitigation Management Matrix (MMM)are followed duringimplementationofthe proposedproject.
A broad-based social assessment will be carried out in early 2007 to build upon the preliminary assessment. The issues faced by women and their needs will be assessed separately in this report (the preliminary assessment that has been done did not involve separate interviews with the women members o f the households). Female social specialists will be part o f the team. A Social Management Plan (SMP) will be developed based on this assessment. The broader assessment will identify the specific training needs o f the households, in particular women, and the SMP will identify appropriate training programs that may help them obtain jobs in the industrial park in the construction and, inparticular the operational phase. The SMP will also provide recommendations on how the industrial park operations may help improve the supply o f social services, inparticular for women who, as the preliminary assessment shows, are severely deprived o f these services. Strategies for introducing good working practices inthe industrial units to be located in the parks, including the treatment of women workers and child labor will also be spelt out. The implementation o f the SMP will require dedicated attention to this.
An Environmental and Social Management Framework (ESMF) has beenprepared for the project and identifies the specific measures to be taken to implement the EMP and the SMP. In addition to dealing with the impact already predicted based on currently known design parameters, the Framework also outlines an approach to deal with environmental and social impact o f sub-projectshnfrastructural interventions that will be identified later, such as land fill sites, location o f power distribution line linking

The ESMF contains a summary o f the EMP, plans for an SMP, the Mitigation Management Matrices for the two parks and an action plan to operationalize the EMP and SMP.
An international expert will be hired as an Environmental Manager in AISA for 18 months to help implement the ESMF. The project will provide funding for this. He/she will be assisted by two local experts, an Environmental Officer and a Social Development Officer, who will be funded by AISA.

The overalllegal and regulatory framework
The EMP and SMP will be implemented in the context o f the overall legislative and regulatory framework for environmental management in Afghanistan. Two important aspects o f this framework are the Environmental ProtectionAct approved by the Afghanistan cabinet inDecember 2005 and the Afghan National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA) established in 2005. The Act spells out frameworks for managing natural resource conservation, biodiversity, drinking water, pollution control, and environmental education, and clarifies the administrative roles at the national level and coordination with provincial authorities. NEPA i s a regulatory authority and mainly responsible for developing and implementing national environmental policies and strategies in order to integrate environmental issues and sustainable development approaches into the legal and regulatory frameworks. NEPA i s also responsible for assessing the effectiveness o f implementation o f the environmental legislations and regulations and related measures. NEPA i s expected to actively coordinate and cooperate with Ministries, Provincial Councils and District and Village Councils, public bodies and private sector on all environment related issues. The Afghanistan Environmental ProtectionAct empowers NEPA to take legal action against non-compliance o f environmental legislations and regulations and impose penalties. NEPA i s a newly established agency and lacks the capacity to carry out its mandate effectively. This i s particularly true o f its provincial offices."

doc.repnme: Afghanistan - Private Sector Development Support Project
doc.abstracts: The private sector development support project for Afghanistan aims to increase the volume of private investment and productive jobs in Afghanistan. The specific goals that will contribute to this are: to enhance the provision of land and infrastructural services for enterprise development; to enhance the capacity of government agencies to analyze private sector development (PSD) issues, and develop and implement PSD-related strategies, policies and programs. Enhance the capacity of government agencies to promote Afghanistan as an investment destination and provide investment facilitation services. By helping to address the land constraint, this project will attract private investment in a variety of sectors, including but not limited to manufacturing, agribusiness, and smaller scale infrastructure projects. The industrial park will help stimulate the local economy generate employment, and raise much needed tax revenues.
